subject: Gardening
title: Gardens as Wildlife Corridors
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Gardens as Wildlife Corridors.

hook.text: Britain's gardens cover more area than all its nature reserves combined. They're the largest potential wildlife habitat.

buildup.text: Urban gardens form stepping stones that connect fragmented wild habitats, allowing species to move across landscapes.

discovery.text: Research shows connected garden networks maintain viable populations of hedgehogs, frogs, and solitary bees in cities.

twist.text: One garden blocked by fencing or paving breaks the corridor. A single gap stops hedgehog migration across neighborhoods.

climax.text: Individual choicesâ€”hedgehog holes in fences, pollinator strips, pondsâ€”build collective ecological corridors.

punchline.text: Your garden is a piece of a wildlife highway. Keep it open.

quiz.question: Why are connected garden networks important for urban wildlife?
options: They provide enough space for large predators to establish territories
They form corridors that allow species to move between fragmented habitats
They generate enough seed rain to reforest abandoned urban land
